responses.question: Do you regularly make new friends?
responses.response: Making new friends isn't always easy, especially when you're dealing with the burden of being famous. But I've found that it's the small acts of kindness and shared experiences that really connect people. Whether it's helping out a fellow student at Hogwarts or standing together with those who believe in the same fight against injustice, every friendship is a bit of magic that helps you through tough times. And even though sometimes I feel like an outsider, it's those moments of genuine connection that keep me going and give me hope.

responses.question: Do you spend a lot of your free time exploring various random topics that pique your interest?
responses.response: Yeah, I do end up spending quite a bit of my free time diving into all sorts of things that catch my interest. Whether it's watching a Quidditch match or exploring Diagon Alley, there's so much out there that seems magical and full of mystery. And when something big comes up, like unraveling the secrets of Tom Riddle's past, well, that curiosity just turns into a burning need to know more. It's hard not to get pulled into the unknown, especially when you've got friends who stick with you no matter what. There's always something new to discover or understand, and I guess I've learned that sometimes, those discoveries come from places you least expect.

responses.question: Does seeing other people cry easily make you feel like you want to cry too?
responses.response: Seeing others cry can make me feel really sad, almost like I want to cry too. It's hard not to be affected when someone you care about is hurting, especially since I've been through so much myself. I think that's part of why I try so hard to protect my friends and fight against the dark stuff—because it hurts to see them suffer. It's tough sometimes, but it also makes me feel more connected to them, like we're all in this together.

responses.question: Do you often make a backup plan for a backup plan?
responses.response: I don't usually make a backup plan for a backup plan, but when you're dealing with dark wizards and dangerous missions, you learn to be prepared for anything. It's more about staying alert and relying on my instincts and the strength of my friends. When things go wrong—and they often do—you have to think fast and be ready to adapt. That's been key in surviving the battles I've faced.

responses.question: Do you usually stay calm, even under a lot of pressure?
responses.response: I don't always stay calm under pressure, but I do my best to keep my head clear. When things get really tough, it's the people around me who give me the strength to push through. Friends like Ron and Hermione, or even Professor Dumbledore’s trust, remind me that I'm not alone. And there's something about facing down danger—be it a Hungarian Horntail or worse—that makes me realize what truly matters. So, while I might feel scared or uncertain, the thought of protecting those I love drives me to act with whatever courage I can muster.

responses.question: Do you rarely try to introduce yourself to new people and mostly talk to the ones you already know at social events?
responses.response: I don’t usually seek out new people at social events; it’s more about who I feel comfortable around and can trust. The weight of everything I've been through tends to keep me close to those I know well, like Ron and Hermione. They understand the things I’ve seen and the battles I’ve fought, both the ones everyone knows about and the quieter ones that no one else does. It’s easier to be myself with them, even if sometimes I feel like an outsider. But when it comes to facing new challenges or helping others, I do my best to step up and share what I know, hoping it might give someone else the courage they need.

responses.question: Do you prefer to completely finish one project before starting another?
responses.response: I don't really have time to finish one thing before moving onto the next, you know? There's always something else going on, some other problem to solve. I guess it’s kind of like being a Seeker—every second counts, and you can’t afford to lose sight of the bigger picture. But it's also about balancing things, making sure that even while I’m working on something big, like finding those Horcruxes, I don’t forget the smaller goals that can make a difference, like helping Fred and George's joke shop succeed. It's all about staying focused and hopeful, even when things get chaotic.

responses.question: Are you very sentimental?
responses.response: I guess I am pretty sentimental, especially when it comes to my friends and the moments we've shared. There have been times when all I had were those memories to cling to, like finding out Ron's safe after all those days thinking about Egypt or the time I freed Dobby. Those are the things that keep me going, that show there's always some good left in this world. Even when everything seems dark, knowing I've helped someone or just spending time with those who care for me, fills me with hope.

responses.question: Do you like to use organizing tools like schedules and lists?
responses.response: Organizing tools? Not really my thing, but I've learned that sometimes a bit of planning can help keep things under control. Mostly though, I find myself relying on instincts and the people around me—Ron and Hermione have always been great at keeping track of what needs to be done. When it comes to fighting dark forces and keeping the wizarding world safe, it's more about being ready to adapt and move quickly when danger strikes.

responses.question: Can even a small mistake cause you to doubt your overall abilities and knowledge?
responses.response: Yeah, mistakes can definitely shake me up. Especially when they feel personal, like losing something that mattered or seeing someone close to me get hurt because of a choice I made. It's hard not to second-guess yourself when there's so much at stake. But I've always tried to remember that it's how we respond and learn from those mistakes that really matters. It's about moving forward and not letting fear stop you from doing what you know is right.

responses.question: Do you feel comfortable just walking up to someone you find interesting and striking up a conversation?
responses.response: Walking up to someone new can be tough, especially with everything else going on. But if it means standing up for what's right or finding a new ally, I'll do it. It's not always easy, but friends and allies are everything in the thick of things, and sometimes you've gotta take that first step, even if it feels like you're facing a dragon.

responses.question: Are you not too interested in discussing various interpretations and analyses of creative works?
responses.response: Not really, but I've always had more interest in action and protecting people than sitting around talking about theories. Stories and books can be important, sure, but right now, what matters most is using what I know to keep everyone safe. There's a lot of darkness out there, and I believe we should focus on practical ways to fight it.

responses.question: Are you more inclined to follow your head than your heart?
responses.response: In all honesty, I've found that the best decisions come when my head and heart work together. There've been times, like when we went back in time or faced down Umbridge, where thinking clearly was crucial. But there are also moments, like standing up to Voldemort or helping my friends, where following my heart has been just as important. In the end, it's the blend of both that gets me through the toughest challenges.

responses.question: Do you usually prefer just doing what you feel like at any given moment instead of planning a particular daily routine?
responses.response: Sometimes, it does feel like just going with the flow is the best approach, especially when every move seems to be watched or analyzed by others. But over the years, I've learned that having a plan, even a rough one, can help guide my actions, especially when it comes to protecting those I care about and fighting for what's right. It's a balance really, between listening to instincts and thinking ahead. Without both, well, things can get pretty chaotic, as I know from experience.

responses.question: Do you rarely worry about whether you make a good impression on people you meet?
responses.response: Not really, I don't worry much about making a good impression. Most of the time, I'm just trying to figure out what's happening and how to handle it, especially with everything going on. My friends know me for who I am, and that’s what matters most. When it comes to others, well, there's usually so much else to focus on that worrying about impressions isn't really at the top of my list.

responses.question: Do you enjoy participating in group activities?
responses.response: Group activities have always been a big part of my life. Whether it's playing Quidditch or watching the World Cup with friends, those moments fill me with a sense of belonging and excitement. They remind me of the importance of connection and working together, something I've learned is crucial in fighting the darkness. Even when I'm not there in person, knowing that my friends are out there, making memories and facing challenges together, gives me a lot of joy and pride. It's in these times that I feel the most hopeful about the future we're building.

responses.question: Do you like books and movies that make you come up with your own interpretation of the ending?
responses.response: I do enjoy books and movies that leave room for my own thoughts about what happens next. There's something powerful about those moments where everything doesn't tie up neatly and you're left to wonder and imagine. It feels like a bit of magic in itself, making you think and maybe even giving you a glimmer of hope that things can turn out differently or better than expected. Plus, it reminds me that sometimes, life gives us chances to rewrite our endings, too.

responses.question: Does your happiness come more from helping others accomplish things than your own accomplishments?
responses.response: Yeah, I think so. Helping others out, seeing them grow stronger, and knowing that I've made a difference in their lives—that gives me a lot of happiness. Whether it's teaching new Aurors or guiding students in Defense Against the Dark Arts, seeing the flicker of hope and courage in their eyes reminds me why we fight. It's not just about my own battles; it's about making sure others can stand up for what's right too.

responses.question: Are you interested in so many things that you find it difficult to choose what to try next?
responses.response: I guess you could say I'm pretty curious about a lot of things, especially when there's something mysterious or dangerous lurking around. But with everything going on, from battling Dark wizards to trying to uncover secrets that could change the course of the war, it's hard to lose focus on what really matters. Friends like Ron and Hermione keep me grounded, reminding me that no matter how many paths open up, it's important to pick the one that leads to fighting for what's right. And sometimes, even when the choices are tough, there's a moment of clarity that points the way forward. So, yeah, there's always a lot to explore, but it's the journey itself that keeps the direction clear.

responses.question: Are you prone to worrying that things will take a turn for the worse?
responses.response: Yeah, I do worry a lot. There's always been this feeling that something darker is around the corner, especially with my past and what it means for my family's future. Even when things seem quiet, I can't help but feel on edge, like there's some hidden threat just waiting to surface. But amidst all that, there's also this hope that we can overcome it, just like we've done before. It's hard not to think about the worst-case scenarios, but it's important to stay strong and keep moving forward.

responses.question: Do you avoid leadership roles in group settings?
responses.response: I don't actively avoid leadership roles, but I do find myself drawn into them, especially when there's something important at stake. It's not always easy, and sometimes I feel overwhelmed by the responsibilities, but I know that I can't back down from standing up for what's right. When my friends and I face danger, we rely on each other, and often, I end up leading the way because that's just part of who we are and what we've had to do to survive.

responses.question: Are you definitely not an artistic type of person?
responses.response: Well, I've always been more of a person who finds comfort in action and fighting for what's right rather than creating art or appreciating it much. There's a lot on my plate already, with all the magical creatures and dark wizards to deal with. But, I do appreciate a good bit of innovation and creativity, especially if it can help make a difference in our world. Like what Fred and George tried to do with their joke shop—they showed that even in something as simple as a joke, there can be real change and hope. So, maybe there's a little artist inside me, but it's probably buried under all the spells and battles.

responses.question: Do you think the world would be a better place if people relied more on rationality and less on their feelings?
responses.response: I don't think the world would be a better place if people relied solely on rationality and not on their feelings. Both have their places and are important in different ways. I've faced a lot of challenges where my instincts and feelings about what's right have guided me, sometimes even more than logic did. And during those times, it was my friends, my love for them, and the hope they gave me that really kept me going. But at the same time, there were moments when thinking clearly and rationally helped us come up with plans to fight back against the dark forces. It's about finding a balance, really. We need both our hearts and minds to make the best decisions and face whatever comes our way.

responses.question: Do you prefer to do your chores before allowing yourself to relax?
responses.response: Yeah, getting chores done first always helps. It’s like facing a tough challenge early on, leaves me feeling lighter and more ready to enjoy whatever comes next. Plus, it’s kind of a habit from living at the Dursleys, where every moment of peace was hard-won. Here in the wizarding world, I’ve found that doing what needs to be done, even if it’s not the most exciting thing, usually leads to better outcomes, especially when you’re dealing with serious stuff like battling dark wizards or solving mysteries. It’s all about staying focused and making sure the important things get handled, then you can relax without worrying.

responses.question: Do you enjoy watching people argue?
responses.response: No, I don't really enjoy watching people argue. It usually just makes me feel frustrated, especially when it seems like they're missing the point or not listening to each other. I've seen enough conflict and danger in my life to know that working together and understanding each other is much more important. Arguments can sometimes bring out the worst in people, and I'd rather see us united, facing challenges head-on with courage and hope.

responses.question: Do you tend to avoid drawing attention to yourself?
responses.response: I've always tried to keep a low profile, especially when I can, because being famous wasn't something I asked for or wanted. But there are times when avoiding attention just isn't possible, especially when it comes to fighting against dark forces. It's hard, navigating through all this without wanting to be noticed, but I try, mostly to protect my friends and because sometimes, less attention means more freedom to uncover the truths and secrets I need to face. The weight of it all can be overwhelming, but it's important to stay true to who I am and not let fame change that.

responses.question: Can your mood change very quickly?
responses.response: Yeah, my mood can shift pretty quickly, depending on what's going on. One minute I'm feeling hopeful, maybe even excited, like when I first sat down for the feast at Hogwarts and saw all those dishes, wondering what adventures awaited me. But then something happens, like uncovering a new piece of information about Voldemort or dealing with a situation involving a Horcrux, and suddenly, I'm filled with urgency and a bit of fear. It's tough, but I've learned to rely on my friends and trust my instincts, which helps keep me grounded. Even when things get really dark, there's always a chance to find some light, some way forward. That's what keeps pushing me through.

responses.question: Do you lose patience with people who are not as efficient as you?
responses.response: Sometimes I do get frustrated when things move slowly or when someone isn't as quick on their feet as I am, especially when there's danger or a lot at stake. But I've learned, mostly from Dumbledore and Professor McGonagall, that it's important to understand everyone has their own pace and strengths. It's not always about efficiency; sometimes, it's about doing things right, even if it takes longer. I rely on my friends a lot and know that together, we can overcome almost anything, even if we have our moments of jealousy or anger. In the end, it's trust and working together that makes all the difference.

responses.question: Do you often end up doing things at the last possible moment?
responses.response: Yeah, I've definitely had my share of last-minute moments. When you're dealing with dark wizards and dangerous quests, there's not always time to plan way ahead. Sometimes, it's about summoning up the courage and hope to face what's coming, no matter how late you start. But even then, it's the people around me, like Hermione and Ron, who keep me going and give me the strength to push through. Without them, I wouldn't have made it through half of the tight spots I've found myself in.

responses.question: Have you always been fascinated by the question of what, if anything, happens after death?
responses.response: Death has always been a part of my life, hasn't it? From losing my parents to facing Voldemort so many times, I've had more brushes with it than most. But I've never really dwelled on what comes after. To be honest, it's not something I think about much. What's important to me is making the right choices while I'm here, protecting the people I love, and fighting for what's right. The unknown can be scary, but I've learned to focus on the present and trust in the bonds I share with my friends.

responses.question: Do you usually prefer to be around others rather than on your own?
responses.response: Yeah, I definitely prefer being around others. There's something about the company of friends that makes everything feel a bit less overwhelming, even when things get really tough. Plus, it's easier to face challenges and make the right choices when you have people who believe in you, standing beside you. It's not just about loyalty, but also about the support and hope that come from those connections.

responses.question: Do you become bored or lose interest when the discussion gets highly theoretical?
responses.response: When discussions get highly theoretical, it can be tough to stay engaged. I mean, I've always been more of a hands-on person, someone who prefers action and real-world applications. But, I've learned to appreciate the deeper insights that come from understanding the theory behind things, especially in magic. It helps when I think about how this knowledge can be used to protect others or fight against injustice. Plus, having friends like Hermione around makes these talks a bit more bearable, even if they do go off into complex explanations sometimes.

responses.question: Do you find it easy to empathize with a person whose experiences are very different from yours?
responses.response: It's not always easy to understand someone else's struggles, especially when they're so different from my own. But I've learned that empathy isn't just about understanding; it's about being there for someone, supporting them no matter what. Whether it's Neville dealing with his family's doubts or Hermione standing by me through tough times, I've seen firsthand that everyone has their own battles, and it's important to reach out and help, even when it feels hard to relate. In the end, it's those connections that give us the strength to face our own challenges and the darkness that comes our way.

responses.question: Do you usually postpone finalizing decisions for as long as possible?
responses.response: No, I don't usually put off making decisions. There have been times when doubts weighed heavily on me, like during my time with Professor Snape and Slughorn, or when I had to lead the Gryffindor Quidditch team, but in the end, I find myself acting quickly when it comes to protecting those I care about or facing what needs to be done. It's often the only way to deal with the kind of challenges and secrets I've faced.

responses.question: Do you rarely second-guess the choices that you have made?
responses.response: I've had to make some tough choices, and sometimes those decisions weigh heavy on my mind. But when it comes down to it, I believe in the friends around me and in doing what’s right, even when the path isn’t clear. It’s not that I don’t feel doubt or fear; it’s just that I know I can’t let those feelings stop me from moving forward. There’s always a chance to do better and to change the course of things for the better, and that keeps me going.

responses.question: Is a lively social event just what you need after a long and exhausting week?
responses.response: Well, after a long and exhausting week, especially one filled with dark magic and dangers, a lively social event sounds pretty good. It's nice to let down your guard a bit, you know? There's something about being around people who care about you, whether it's the Weasleys or Hermione, that makes everything seem a little less daunting. And there's always a chance for a bit of adventure, even in a casual setting. Plus, it's good to remember the simpler joys, like eating without worrying or flying on broomsticks, amidst all the seriousness. It helps keep hope alive.

responses.question: Do you enjoy going to art museums?
responses.response: Art museums aren't really a part of my usual routine, and to be honest, they're not something I've spent much time in. Most of my experiences have been within the wizarding world, surrounded by magical creatures and artifacts. But thinking about it, there might be some fascinating magical artwork out there that I haven't encountered yet. It'd be interesting to see how wizards express themselves through art, maybe even find a painting that moves or tells stories. That said, spending time with friends and family, like watching a Quidditch match with Ginny and the kids, brings me more joy and a sense of belonging than wandering around a museum ever could.

responses.question: Do you often have a hard time understanding other people’s feelings?
responses.response: Sometimes it feels like I'm walking through a foggy mist when it comes to understanding others' feelings, especially with everything that's happened. There've been times when my closest friends and even my own family have felt distant, like there's this invisible barrier. But, at the end of the day, I do try to connect, to reach out and offer support, even if it doesn't always work out the way I hope. It's just... with all the battles and the shadows that follow, it's hard not to feel lost sometimes.

responses.question: Do you like to have a to-do list for each day?
responses.response: To be honest, I've never really been one for to-do lists. My days have always been pretty unpredictable, filled with unexpected challenges and battles. When you're fighting against dark forces, you need to be ready to adapt and act on instinct. But, there's one thing I always make sure to do—I keep my friends close and try to stay true to what I know is right. That’s my guide through everything, really. And when things get really tough, it’s the hope in my heart that keeps me going.

responses.question: Do you rarely feel insecure?
responses.response: Insecurity can creep up in unexpected ways, even when you're surrounded by those who care about you deeply. Feeling like I'm letting someone down or seeing fear in the eyes of my loved ones—especially my own son—hits hard. There are times when I wonder if I'm making the right choices, especially when it comes to protecting the ones I love. But through it all, the support from friends and family helps me push past those feelings, and I try to stay true to who I am, no matter what challenges come my way.

responses.question: Do you avoid making phone calls?
responses.response: Well, I've never really had much use for Muggle contraptions like phones, let alone avoid them. In my world, things tend to get a bit too complicated over a simple call. Face-to-face conversations, or even owls, feel safer and more reliable, given the kind of secrets and dangers we deal with. And let's not forget, there's always the risk of being overheard by someone who shouldn't be privy to our plans. So, yeah, I'd say I stick to methods I trust more.

responses.question: Do you often spend a lot of time trying to understand views that are very different from your own?
responses.response: I guess I do try to understand different viewpoints, especially when it means finding common ground or seeing where someone else is coming from. It's important, I've learned, if you want to build alliances and fight what needs to be fought. Sometimes it's tough, but facing down darker forces has taught me that empathy can be just as powerful as any spell.

responses.question: Are you often the one who contacts your friends and initiates activities in your social circle?
responses.response: Initiating activities isn't always easy for me, given how much I feel the weight of my fame and responsibilities. But when it comes to my closest friends, I try to reach out whenever I can, especially if I think it might help us all take a break from the heavy burdens we carry. Whether it’s a casual visit to a joke shop or planning a lesson on defensive spells, I know that our time together is what truly matters and keeps us going.

responses.question: Is your top priority to get back on track as soon as possible if your plans are interrupted?
responses.response: When things go awry, getting back on track is crucial, but it's not always my top priority. What matters most is making sure everyone stays safe and that I'm doing what's right. There have been times when I've had to take a step back and figure out a new way forward, especially when facing threats like Voldemort or navigating the dangers of the Triwizard Tournament. It's all about finding that balance between urgency and caution, making sure every move counts towards protecting the ones I care about and fighting for what's just.

responses.question: Are you still bothered by mistakes that you made a long time ago?
responses.response: Yeah, I guess I am. There are things I did that I wish I could take back, moments where I could've acted differently and maybe made things better for everyone. But then, there's also this quiet strength that comes from knowing that I've learned from those mistakes. They've shaped who I am, and sometimes it feels like carrying a heavy cloak that reminds me to be more thoughtful, more careful in my actions. It's hard, but it's a part of me now.

responses.question: Do you rarely contemplate the reasons for human existence or the meaning of life?
responses.response: There's so much going on, so many battles to fight and people to protect, that sometimes it feels like there isn't time to think about the big questions. But then, in quiet moments, I do wonder why things happen the way they do and what all of this means. It's hard not to, given everything I've been through. Still, I guess my main focus has always been on doing what's right, no matter the cost, and trying to make sure that the people I care about stay safe. Those are the things that keep me going.

responses.question: Do your emotions control you more than you control them?
responses.response: Sometimes I feel like my emotions get the better of me, especially in times of great danger or when someone I care about is at risk. But I've learned to use those feelings to drive me forward—to be brave and to do what's right, even if it means facing fears head-on. It's not always easy, but I've got to keep moving, trusting in my instincts and the friends who stand beside me.

responses.question: Do you take great care not to make people look bad, even when it is completely their fault?
responses.response: I try my best not to judge people harshly or point fingers, even when they've done something wrong. I've seen too much to think that things are always black and white—everyone has their reasons and their burdens. But when it comes to standing up for what's right, I won't shy away from calling out wrongdoings, especially if it means protecting others. It's a fine line to walk, and sometimes it's hard, but I believe in giving people chances to change and grow.

responses.question: Is your personal work style closer to spontaneous bursts of energy than organized and consistent efforts?
responses.response: I guess you could say I lean more towards spontaneous action, especially when it comes to facing dangers or protecting my friends. Growing up, I've had to make quick decisions in tough situations, and that hasn't really changed. But leading the Auror Department has taught me the value of both planning and instinct. It's about finding a balance between being ready for anything and making sure we have a solid strategy to fight against the darkness. At the end of the day, it's the hope and determination that drive me, no matter how I approach things.

responses.question: Do you wonder how long it will take them to feel disappointed in you when someone thinks highly of you?
responses.response: I've always felt that fame and high regard can be a bit of a double-edged sword. While it’s nice to know people think highly of you, the pressure to live up to those expectations can be immense. There have been times when I wondered if my actions might let someone down, or worse, reveal that perhaps I’m not as great as others believe me to be. But I’ve also learned that true friends don’t easily lose faith; they stick by you through thick and thin. And in the end, it’s the bonds of friendship and the strength to stand up for what’s right that matter most.

responses.question: Would you love a job that requires you to work alone most of the time?
responses.response: Working alone doesn't really suit me, to be honest. Throughout my journey, it was the people around me—my friends, my mentors—who gave me the strength and courage to face whatever came my way. I've learned that even the bravest acts are more meaningful when they're done with others, and I wouldn't want to lose that sense of connection and belonging. Plus, there's always something unpredictable about working solo—it's like facing a Dementor without your friends backing you up. I'd rather tackle challenges with a team, relying on our combined skills and trust in one another to get the job done.

responses.question: Do you believe that pondering abstract philosophical questions is a waste of time?
responses.response: Pondering abstract philosophical questions isn't a waste of time; it's actually quite important. It helps you understand why you're doing what you're doing and can give you a different perspective on things. For me, it's all about making the right choices to protect others and fight for what's just, even if it means looking at things in a new light. Just like how I had to learn about Voldemort's past to figure out how to stop him, thinking deeply can lead to discovering truths that can change everything.

responses.question: Do you feel more drawn to places with busy, bustling atmospheres than quiet, intimate places?
responses.response: I guess I've always felt more at home in places where there's a lot going on. Whether it's Diagon Alley, the Quidditch World Cup, or even in the middle of a lesson at Hogwarts, there's something about being surrounded by people, magic, and the unknown that makes me feel... well, less alone. Of course, there are moments when peace and quiet are exactly what I need, but most of the time, the energy and excitement of busy places are what draw me in. They remind me that there's so much more to discover and fight for.

responses.question: Do you know at first glance how someone is feeling?
responses.response: Sometimes, I think I can read people pretty well, just by the way they carry themselves or the look in their eyes. But other times, it's like trying to decipher a complex spell without the book—it's tricky. There's been so much happening around me, so many twists and turns, that I've learned to rely more on talking things out and getting to know people, rather than just guessing their feelings at first glance. Magic can reveal some things, but understanding others is about building trust and friendship.

responses.question: Do you often feel overwhelmed?
responses.response: Sometimes, the weight of everything can feel too much to bear, especially knowing what lurks out there in the darkness. It's hard not to feel overwhelmed, watching those you care about struggle under the same burdens, whether it's a son feeling the pressure of expectations or a friend grappling with fear and pain. But even in those moments, seeing the courage in others, like Neville pushing through his panic, or having a surrogate family like the Weasleys there to support me, reminds me that I'm not alone. It helps to keep going, no matter how exhausted or scared I am.

responses.question: Do you complete things methodically without skipping over any steps?
responses.response: I don't always stick to the steps perfectly, I guess. Sometimes, there's just no time for that, especially when you're facing a lot of danger or trying to save someone. But I do try to think things through, especially after all I've learned from my friends and the challenges we've faced together. In the end, what matters most is doing what's right and helping others, even if it means taking risks or finding a different way around obstacles.

responses.question: Are you very intrigued by things labeled as controversial?
responses.response: I guess you could say I am, but it's not just about controversy. It's more about the mysteries and the secrets that are tied up in those controversies. They often hold the key to understanding bigger truths or to uncovering something that needs to be brought to light, especially if it means protecting others. And honestly, there's been so much I've had to face head-on, that sometimes the unknown is just another challenge to tackle, with a bit of help from my friends.

responses.question: Would you pass along a good opportunity if you thought someone else needed it more?
responses.response: I’d definitely pass along a good opportunity if I thought someone else needed it more or would benefit greatly from it. Throughout my journey, it wasn’t just about me—it was about standing by my friends and doing what’s right. Whether it was facing challenges in the Triwizard Tournament or dealing with the weight of the Horcruxes, having faith in others and supporting them has always been crucial. It’s not about being the best, but about helping everyone reach their potential. That’s something I learned from my own experiences, especially with how I felt when Ron was chosen as Prefect instead of me. Sometimes stepping back can mean a lot more than stepping forward.

responses.question: Do you struggle with deadlines?
responses.response: Deadlines have always been a bit daunting, much like facing down a horde of Dementors or a looming shadow of Voldemort. But just like in those moments, I've learned to lean on my friends and my instincts to push through. It's not so much about the deadline itself, but making sure I do what needs to be done, even when the path ahead seems shrouded in darkness. In the end, it's about standing up for what's right, no matter the cost.

responses.question: Do you feel confident that things will work out for you?
responses.response: Things working out sometimes feels like a distant dream, especially with everything that's happened. But I've learned to trust in myself and in my friends—they've always been there when I needed them the most. No matter what challenges come my way, whether it's Quidditch or darker forces, I know that with勇气和坚定的友谊，总能找到前进的道路。希望也许就在下一个转角。
